text.p: Kaiser Aluminum Corp said Thursday it took a $19.7 million pre-tax restructuring charge in the second quarter. It also said it had begun to see the initial effects of its performance improvements program.

The company today reported second-quarter net income of $13.7 million, or $0.16 a share, against $8.2 million, or $0.09 a share, a year earlier. The 1997 figure includes the restructuring charge, equal to $0.17 a share pre-tax, and also a $12.5 million tax provision gain, also $0.17 a share.
The aluminum producer's results topped a First Call consensus earnings estimate of $0.08.

Chief Executive George Haymaker, in a statement, attributed the earnings increase to improved operating efficiencies; higher shipments of alumina, primary aliminum and fabricated aluminum products; and modestly higher alumina prices.
The company said it took the $19.7 million charge to restructure its fabricated products businesses, including a planned closing of its forgings plant in Erie, Pa.
The write-down of the Erie plant's assets was partly offset by transferring some assets to a new wheel manufacturing joint venture, AKW LP, it said.
"In the second quarter, the company began to see the initial benefits of the company's $120 million performance improvement program," Haymaker said.
He added, "The full benefits will not be felt until 1998."
Kaiser's stock slipped 1/16 to 13-1/16 Thursday morning.
